content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Went through all the tests manually, everything adds up correctly. The large inputs make binary search pretty much necessary which is nice.
One small thing @Diabetos found that sqrt(7*R/8) works for everything except F=1. Might want to add a test with R=1 to block that shortcut, but up to you.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: bonne chanse

I'm not sure how you want the puzzle to be solved, but I immediatly thought "Well, f* f/7 is close enough to f²/7" so I did: "p ((7*gets.to_i/8)**0.5).round", it works, but it is an approximation, in fact, the only number it doesn't work with is F = 1. So if you want you clash to be protected from it, you should add that test, if you don't, that would become a math problem rather than a programming one, I'm not a huge fan of those

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As @ProDige_cheese has pointed out, this clash can be solved without the use of binary search so long as you limit the search range of F appropriately. I used a bit of math to figure out that R ≥ sqrt(F/2) and hence came up with:

r=int(input())
f=int((r//2)**0.5)
while f*(f+f//7)<r:f+=1
print(f)

I would advise against trying to force a binary search solution as that might make this clash too difficult for beginners to solve. That being said, I think the clash is currently in a good state in that sub-optimal solutions are still possible whilst still encouraging optimisation.

I found the goal statement slightly confusing, and would reword part of it so it is clearer, something like e.g.: "Each floor has an associated magic level that also gets higher the more you go up and given by following formula: …. The wizard of this place wants that you take him to floor [[F]] but only remembers its associated magic level [[R]] and not the floor number itself".

Great idea but it seems too simple since this programm works :
f = 0
while True:
     if magic(f) is R: break
     f ++
print(f)

You could probably add test cases with much bigger R to force the binary search.
If it was intentional, then your solution is a bit overkill :)

* The player shouldn't be expected to know the formula required for the problem.

* The clash currently lacks any key programming elements such as lists, sets, dictionaries, string manipulation, loops, conditions…

Please add one or more programming elements so that the clash is more of a programming problem than a physics/maths problem.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback. I will update my question.
Thanks for the feedback... I have done a bit of work to ensure the binary search. But still, I think this is the safe range possible.
Please make sure you've solved a contribution using your own code before you approve it. Thanks.

Thank you for revising the problem. However, it still has the same underlying issue: it reduces directly to a simple mathematical formula, since the answer is always (R + 7)/3. Please further modify the problem to avoid a direct closed-form solution, and include one or more programming elements as previously mentioned.

Also note that each test and its validator should cover the same scenario with slightly different inputs and outputs (if applicable). No two cases should be the same unless the case is an edge case.
Thanks again for the feedback. I have redone the problem. Please provide your valuable feedback on this as well.

The task itself is fine. Please revise your contribution according to the points below.

Goal
* Please remove the [[variable]] formatting from the magic formula. Instead, apply this formatting to all instances of the variable names [[F]] and [[R]] only (both in the formula and elsewhere).

* To avoid giving an unintended hint about using the "floor" function for some languages, replace "floor(x)" with "⌊x⌋". Likewise, use "⌊F / 7⌋" and "⌊1.9⌋" instead of "floor(F / 7)" and "floor(1.9)".

Cases
* Please revise the cases so that the input values increase progressively. A suggested structure is:

  • Test 1 and Validator 1: 1-digit input
  • Test 2 and Validator 2: 3-digit input
  • Test 3 and Validator 3: 6-digit input
  • Test 4 and Validator 4: 10-digit input
  • Test 5 and Validator 5: 13-digit input

You're encouraged to have more than 4 pairs of cases when necessary.

Thanks.
Thanks again for the feedback. I hope this corrects all the formatting errors, and I have set the test cases to be progressive.

Looking better.

On the safe side, please keep the input numbers below 2^53, as some programming languages on this platform may run into issues with larger values.

Thanks.
